            <suggestion>\1 in to</suggestion>. For websites and computers, other options are 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">log</match> in to</suggestion> or 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">log</match> on to</suggestion>.</message>

            <suggestion>\1 in to</suggestion> . For websites and computers, other options are 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">log</match> in to</suggestion> or 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">log</match> on to</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg:
<message>In EU texts, the word 'action' is used countably with a meaning akin to 
            '<suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">scheme</match></suggestion>', 
            '<suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">measure</match></suggestion>' or 
            '<suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">project</match></suggestion>'. Where 'action' is used countably with this meaning, use one of those words.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>在欧盟的文本中，'action'一词的使用是有意义的，类似于
            '<suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">scheme</match></suggestion> ', 
            '<suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">measure</match></suggestion> ' or 
            '<suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">project</match></suggestion> '. 'action'可以表示这个意思，使用其中一个词。</message>

en_msg: <message>An actor is 'a person who acts in a play, film, broadcast, etc.' or 'a person who puts on a false manner in order to deceive others'. In EU usage, 'actors' are often simply 'the people and/or organisations involved in doing something'. Rework the sentence to avoid the problem. Identify who you are talking about ('international aid organisations', for example) and using the term.</message>
zh_msg: <message>'actor'是“在剧本，电影，广播等中扮演角色的人”。或者“以虚假的方式欺骗​​他人”的人。在欧盟的使用中，“演员”往往只是“参与做某事的人员和/或组织”。重写句子以避免该问题。确定你在说什么（例如“国际援助组织”）并使用该术语。</message>

en_msg: <message>This word is an extraordinary creation… that is both quite impenetrable and slightly childish. Alternatives: <suggestion>participation</suggestion>, <suggestion>involvement</suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>'Actual' is sometimes used to refer to something that is happening now. However, in English it means 'real' or 'existing'. Alternatives: <suggestion>current</suggestion>, <suggestion>present</suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>'Adequate' is frequently used with the meaning of 'appropriate'. However, its actual meaning is closer to 'satisfactory' or sometimes even 'barely satisfactory'. Alternatives: <suggestion>appropriate</suggestion>, <suggestion>suitable</suggestion>, <suggestion>fitting</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg: <message>'Adequate' 经常被用于“适当”的意思。然而，它的实际意义更接近“令人满意”，有时甚至是“勉强令人满意的”。或许试试: <suggestion>appropriate</suggestion> , <suggestion>suitable</suggestion> , <suggestion>fitting</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>In British English, an 'agent' works for a government intelligence agency (CIA, MOSSAD, MI5, G2), runs or represents a service agency (travel agent, estate agent), or represents a company in its dealings with the public (ticket agent, baggage agent, call-centre agent). Alternatives: <suggestion>staff</suggestion>, <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NNS?">employee</match></suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg: <message>在英式英语中， 一个“代理人”为政府情报机构（CIA，MOSSAD，MI5，G2）工作，运营或代表一个服务机构（旅行社，房地产经纪人），或代表一个公司，与公众进行交易（票务代理，行李代理，呼叫中心代理）。 或许试试: <suggestion>staff</suggestion> , <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NNS?">employee</match></suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>The word 'aid' is uncountable when it has the meaning of 'assistance'. With an '-s', it refers to a disease (AIDS) or to devices that help you do something (e.g. 'hearing aids' or 'teaching aids'). Alternatives: <suggestion>aid</suggestion>, <suggestion>subsidies</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg: <message>'aid' 这个词表“援助”的含义时是不可数的。当加了“-S”时是指一种疾病（AIDS）或帮助你做某事的装置（例如助听器或助教）。或许试试: <suggestion>aid</suggestion> , <suggestion>subsidies</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>There are 634 instances of 'with the aim to (do something) in Eurlex. 'With the aim to' takes 'of' + the gerund. Alternatives: <suggestion>with the aim of</suggestion> (doing something), <suggestion>with a view to</suggestion> (doing something, not do something).</message>
zh_msg: <message>欧盟法律法规数据库中有634个例子关于做某事的目的。 目标是+动名词。试试这样: <suggestion>with the aim of</suggestion> (doing something), <suggestion>with a view to</suggestion> (doing something, not do something).</message>

en_msg: <message>When used to mean 'make it possible to', 'allow to', 'permit to', and 'enable to' cannot be used without a grammatical object. 'Allow' must be followed by a noun or pronoun such as 'us'. Alternatives: make it possible to, allow us to, enable us to, allow (an assessment) of.</message>
zh_msg: <message>如果没有语法对象，'allow to', 'permit to', 和'enable to'不能用来表示“使成为可能”的意思。'Allow'后面必须跟一个名词或代词，如'我们'。或者试试: make it possible to, allow us to, enable us to, allow (an assessment) of.</message>

en_msg: <message>The term 'Anglo-Saxon' is generally used to describe 'a member of any of the West Germanic tribes (Angles, Saxons, and Jutes) that settled in Britain from the 5th century AD'. Also, in America, it is used to denominate white people, usually of the Protestant faith ('WASPS'). Alternatives: <suggestion>English-speaking</suggestion> when referring to the countries or the people, <suggestion>British</suggestion> and <suggestion>American</suggestion> ('Australian' or whatever) when referring to agencies, capitalism etc.</message>
zh_msg: <message>“盎格鲁撒克逊”一词通常被用来形容“从五世纪起定居在英国的西日耳曼部落（盎格鲁人、撒克逊人和朱特人）中的一员。此外，在美国，它通常被用来命名有新教信仰的白人。('WASPS') 或许试试: <suggestion>English-speaking</suggestion> when referring to the countries or the people, <suggestion>British</suggestion> and <suggestion>American</suggestion> ('Australian' or whatever) when referring to agencies, capitalism etc.</message>

en_msg: <message>Every now and then a job advertisement appears, saying that the Commission is looking for a 'head of sector to animate 12 staff members'. The new employee will find that he/she is expected to <suggestion>lead</suggestion> or <suggestion>head</suggestion> a team.</message>
zh_msg: <message>时不时就会有一份招聘广告出现，称委员会正在寻找一位'部门主管，为12名员工创造动力'。新员工们的心理预期是<suggestion>lead</suggestion> or <suggestion>head</suggestion> a team.</message>

en_msg: <message>The UK has a fraud office, a national crime agency, drug squads and vice squads. In the EU, we have the European Anti Fraud Office, anti-crime policies, anti-drugs trafficking, and anti-cyber crime investigation. You can usually remove 'anti-'. Alternatives: <suggestion><match no="1" regexp_match="(?i)(anti)-(.*)" regexp_replace="$2" /> \2</suggestion></message>
zh_msg: <message>英国设有欺诈办公室，国家犯罪机构，毒品小组和刑警队。在欧盟，我们拥有欧洲反欺诈办公室，反犯罪政策，反贩毒和反网络犯罪调查。你通常可以把'anti-'删掉。或许试试: <suggestion><match no="1" regexp_match="(?i)(anti)-(.*)" regexp_replace="$2" /> \2</suggestion> </message>

en_msg:
<message>The verb 'articulate' normally means 'to put something into words' (e.g. 'he tried to articulate his fears'). Used intransitively, it means 'to speak' or 'to enunciate'. In EU texts, on the other hand, 'articulate' is commonly used to mean 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">coordinate</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">link</match> together</suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">connect</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">organise</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">structure</match></suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>动词'articulate'通常意味着'将某些东西变成文字'（例如'他试图表达他的恐惧'）。当用作不及物动词时，意思是“说话”或“发音”。另一方面，在欧盟文本中，'articulate'通常被用来表示
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">coordinate</match></suggestion> , 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">link</match> together</suggestion> , 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">connect</match></suggestion> , 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">organise</match></suggestion> , 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">structure</match></suggestion> .</message>

en_msg:
<message>'Articulation' is 'the act or process of speaking or expressing in words'; it is also a synonym for a joint (principally in anatomy, botany and mechanics) and, by extension, the 'state of being jointed together'. Alternatives: 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NNS|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN:U">coordination</match></suggestion>,

en_msg:
<message>If you attribute something to someone, you are saying that he is thought to have made it/produced it. You can also attribute something to a cause ('The EIB attributes this relative underperformance… to the financial crisis'). You cannot, however, attribute aid, compensation, contracts or licences. Alternatives: 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="V.*">allocate</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="V.*">grant</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="V.*">give</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="V.*">award</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="V.*">assign</match></suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>The use of the word 'axis' that is often found in EU documents ('a coherent group of measures with specific goals') appears to derive from the French (possibly from the meaning 'general direction' cited in the 'Petit Robert'). This usage does not exist in English, where the word is used primarily in geometry, anatomy and politics ('the Axis powers' or the 'axis of evil'). Curiously, in EU texts, 'axes' can also be roads, particularly important ones. Use: depending on the context: priority axis = priority; road axis = road (sometimes trunk road); strategic axis = strategic priority etc. If you have to use the EU term here, you really do need to explain it.</message>
zh_msg: <message>在欧盟文献中经常发现的'axis'一词（“具有特定目标的连贯的一组措施”）似乎源自法语（可能来自“Petit Robert”中引用的“一般方向”）。这种用法在英语中不存在，这个词主要用于几何学、解剖学和政治学（“轴心国”或“邪恶轴心”）。奇怪的是，在欧盟文本中，“轴”也可以是道路，尤其是重要的道路。使用：取决于上下文：优先轴=优先权；道路轴=道路（有时是主干道路）；战略轴=战略优先权。如果你必须在这里使用欧盟术语，你真的需要解释它。</message>

en_msg:
<message>Although the use of the word 'badge' to mean '<suggestion>service pass</suggestion>' seems to have gained currency in the English speaking world, it can still not be used to describe a lunch card or the little tag you use to clock in and out at work. Generally speaking it must be something attached to or worn on your outer clothing. There is also no verb 'to badge' in this context. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion>tag</suggestion> for the clocking-in device, and 
            <suggestion>clock in</suggestion> or 
            <suggestion>clock out</suggestion> for the verb. In the school example, the object is actually a 
            <suggestion>lunch card</suggestion>.</message>

en_msg:
<message>'Budget line' is used so often that it has begun to sound right. However, it does not exist in English in the sense in which it is used in the EU institutions. Furthermore, there is no consensus as to what 'budget line' actually refers to (some say 'budget heading' and some 'budget item'). The dictionary definition of 'budget line' is 'the alternative combinations of two different goods that can be purchased with a given income and given prices of the two goods'. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion>budget <match no="2" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">heading</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion>budget <match no="2" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">item</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion>budget <match no="2" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">title</match></suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>“预算线”经常被使用，以至于它开始听起来是正确的。然而，在欧盟机构中，它并不存在于英语中。此外，对于“预算线”实际上指的是什么（有人说“预算标题”和一些“预算项目”），目前还没有达成共识。“预算线”在字典里的定义是“两种不同商品的可选组合，可以用给定的收入以及两种商品的价格购买”。试试:

en_msg:
<message>'Cabinet' (usually pronounced 'cabinay' by English-speaking EU officials and 'cabinet' by others) is the term used at the Commission (and informally at the Court of Auditors) to refer to the private office of a Commissioner (or Member). Other than denoting a piece of furniture, the term is most commonly used in Britain to refer to 'the senior ministers of the British Government'. The 'British cabinet' is therefore 'the principal executive group of British government' and not the private office of the British member of the Commission or Court or the staff thereof. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion>private office</suggestion>, <suggestion>office</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>'Cabinet'（通常由说英语的欧盟官员或其他人来称呼“内阁”）是欧盟委员会（审计院非正式地）使用的术语，指的是一个专员（或成员）的私人办公室。除了表示一件家具外，这个词在英国最常用来指代“英国政府的高级大臣”。因此，“英国内阁”是英国政府的主要行政机构，而不是英国委员会或法院的英国成员或其工作人员的私人办公室。 试试用: 
            <suggestion>private office</suggestion> , <suggestion>office</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>'In case of' does not mean '<suggestion>for</suggestion>' and 'in case' (without of) is not an elegant way of saying '<suggestion>if</suggestion>, '<suggestion>when</suggestion>' or '<suggestion>where</suggestion>'. This may sound a trifle odd to people in 'Brussels', where we often find sentences like 'farmers are subject to possible reductions in case of non-compliance' (= for non-compliance) and 'the fund can be mobilised in case the damage caused by a national disaster exceeds the threshold' (= where it exceeds the threshold)… In regular English 'in case of' is most commonly used in sentences that follow the pattern: 'in case of fire, break glass' (i.e. 'in the event of an (adverse) occurrence, act as follows') and 'in case' (no of) means 'in the event that', or just 'if'.</message>
zh_msg: <message>'In case of'不是说'<suggestion>for</suggestion> ' and 'in case' (without of) is not an elegant way of saying '<suggestion>if</suggestion> , '<suggestion>when</suggestion> ' or '<suggestion>where</suggestion> '. 对布鲁塞尔人来说，这听起来可能有点奇怪，我们经常会发现这样的句子：“农民在不遵守命令的情况下可能遭受减刑”，“如果国家灾难造成的损害超过门槛”，就可以动员资金。在普通英语中，'in case of'最常用于遵循这种句型的句子：“在火灾的情况下，打破玻璃”（即“在发生（不利的）事件时，按以下方式进行））和'in case'（没有of）指的是“事件”，或者仅仅是“如果”。</message>

en_msg:
<message>'Citizen' has become something of a buzzword that EU authors like to include in their texts, presumably to emphasize the concept of 'European citizenship', as introduced under the Maastricht treaty. Actually, this word is decidedly less common in English than in some other languages and, in native texts, it is nearly always used to mean 'a legally recognized subject or national of a state or commonwealth'. The emphasis is very much on nationality, so, for example, if we say that 'steps have been taken to help citizens get back to work', we imply that non-citizens are not expected to benefit. Use 'citizen' only if you really mean 'citizen' and particularly if you wish to exclude non-citizens. Otherwise, use <suggestion>the public</suggestion>, <suggestion>people</suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)?" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">taxpayer</match></suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>'Citizen'已成为欧盟作者喜欢在其文本中加入的流行词，大概是为了强调“马斯特里赫特条约”引入的“欧洲公民身份”概念。实际上，这个词在英语中的使用明显少于其他一些语言，并且在本地文本中，它几乎总是用来表示“法律认可的国家或国家的主体或国家”。例如，如果我们说“已采取措施帮助公民重返工作岗位”，我们意味着非公民不会受益。只有当你真正指“公民”时，才使用“公民”，特别是如果你想排除非公民。否则，用 <suggestion>the public</suggestion> , <suggestion>people</suggestion> , 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)?" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">taxpayer</match></suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>Coherent means 'logical; consistent and orderly' or 'capable of logical and orderly thought'. In the former meaning, it is generally an internal characteristic of an argument or a publication, for example, and in the latter meaning, it is an internal characteristic of a person (e.g. 'he is totally incoherent, he must have been drinking'). In the EU, on the other hand, it is frequently used with the meaning of 'in agreement with' or 'accordant with' (something else). Alternatives: <suggestion>consistent</suggestion>, consistency.</message>
zh_msg: <message>Coherent意味着'合乎逻辑;一致和有序“或”有能力进行逻辑和有序的思考“。例如，就前者而言，它通常是论证或出版物的内部特征，在后者的意义上，它是一个人的内在特征（例如“他是完全不连贯的，他一定是在喝酒”） 。另一方面，在欧盟，它经常被用来表示“同意”或“一致”（其他内容）。试试： <suggestion>consistent</suggestion> , consistency.</message>

en_msg: <message>In the English-speaking world, 'college' normally refers to one type of educational establishment or another (university college, Eton College, etc.). It can also be a body of electors ('electoral college'). In the EU, it is used to mean the actual Court or Commission, as opposed to the institution and its staff. The only context where it is traditionally used in a similar meaning is the ecclesiastical Latinism: 'the college of cardinals' (from Collegium Cardinalium). The term 'college of Commissioners' has become enshrined in EU usage, but we should use the word sparingly when referring to other bodies. Especially when it is used in isolation ('the college' tout court), readers outside the institutions may think we are referring to a school of some sort. Alternatives: <suggestion>Court</suggestion>, <suggestion>Commission</suggestion>. If it is necessary to specify beyond doubt that it was the actual Court, we can say 'the Court itself' or 'the Court's members' ('the Members of the Commission') or even just 'the Members' (or the 'Commissioners').</message>
zh_msg: <message>在说英语的世界里，"college"通常指一种教育机构或另一种（大学学院，伊顿公学等）。它也可以是一个选民团体（'选举团'）。在欧盟，它被用来指实际的法院或委员会，而不是机构及其工作人员。传统上用于类似含义的唯一语境是教会的拉丁语：“红衣主教学院”（来自于红衣主教）。 术语'college of Commissioners'这个词已经成为欧盟用法的一部分，但在谈到其他机构时，我们应该谨慎地使用这个词。 特别是当它被孤立地使用时（'the college' ），机构外的读者可能会认为我们指的是某种学校。 试试: <suggestion>Court</suggestion> , <suggestion>Commission</suggestion> . If it is necessary to specify beyond doubt that it was the actual Court, we can say 'the Court itself' or 'the Court's members' ('the Members of the Commission') or even just 'the Members' (or the 'Commissioners').</message>

en_msg: <message>There are 1,253 instances of the word 'comitology' in EUR Lex. However, not only does the word not exist outside the EU institutions, but it is formed from a misspelt stem (committee has two 'm's and two 't's) and a suffix that means something quite different (ology/logy means 'the science of' or 'the study of') . It is therefore highly unlikely that an outsider would be able to deduce its meaning, even in context. The official term is '<suggestion>committee procedure</suggestion>'.</message>
zh_msg: <message>在欧洲的法律中，'comitology'这个单词出现在1,253个例子中。然而，这个词不仅不存在于欧盟机构之外，而且是由拼写错误形成的（委员会有两个‘M’和两个‘t’）和一个意思是完全不同的东西的后缀（ology/logy 的意思是‘科学’或‘研究’’）。因此，局外人很难推断出其含义，即使在上下文中也是如此。官方术语是 '<suggestion>committee procedure</suggestion> '.</message>

en_msg: <message>'Competence' in its meaning of 'the legal authority of a court or other body to deal with a particular matter' is uncountable in English and therefore does not usually take a plural. We normally speak of the 'powers' of bodies or institutions rather than their 'competences'. Alternatives: <suggestion>powers</suggestion>, <suggestion>jurisdiction</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg: <message>'Competence' 在表“法院或其他机构处理特定事物的法律权威”的含义时在英语中是不可数的，因此通常不采用复数形式。我们通常说的是身体或机构的“权力”，而不是他们的“能力”。试试: <suggestion>powers</suggestion> , <suggestion>jurisdiction</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg:
<message>To 'complete' means to finish, end or terminate. It therefore implies that whatever is being completed was somehow incomplete. In EU texts, however, this word is often used to mean that something extra has been added to supplement something that, in itself, was actually complete beforehand. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">supplement</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">add</match> to</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>To'complete'的意思是完成、结束或终止。因此，它意味着无论什么正在完成，都是不完整的。然而，在欧盟的文本中，这个词经常被用来表示额外的东西被添加来补充一些东西，而这些东西本身实际上是事先完成的。试试：
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">supplement</match></suggestion> , 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">add</match> to</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>We often find paragraphs in reports that begin with 'concerning XYZ, the Court found that…', instead of 'with regard to'. This sounds very odd in English. The rather endearing Gallicism 'for what concerns' is also remarkably common, even in published documents (30 hits in EUR Lex, many of which are recent). In English, there is usually no need to start a sentence with a direct reference to the subject matter, as you would in certain other languages, and a different word-order might be better. Furthermore, where this introductory phrase merely repeats the paragraph heading, it should be eliminated altogether. Alternatives: <suggestion>with regard to</suggestion>, <suggestion>in respect of</suggestion>, <suggestion>in terms of</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg: <message>我们经常在报告中找到以'concerning XYZ, the Court found that…'为开头的段落,而不是'with regard to'。 这听起来很奇怪。另一种非常讨喜的形式'for what concerns'也非常常见,甚至是在已出版的文件中（有30次点击，其中许多是最近的）。在英语中，通常没有必要像你在其他语言中那样直接引用主题，而不同的单词顺序可能会更好。 此外，如果这个介绍性短语仅仅重复了该段的标题，则应该完全去掉。试试：<suggestion>with regard to</suggestion> , <suggestion>in respect of</suggestion> , <suggestion>in terms of</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>A number of adjectives in English have a different meaning when used after the noun. One of these is 'concerned'. Before the noun, it means 'worried', after the noun, it means 'involved in or affected by something'. A concerned official is therefore one that is worried about something, whereas if you want to contact the official responsible for something, you should write to the official concerned. Alternatives: <suggestion>\2 \1</suggestion></message>
zh_msg: <message>在名词后使用的许多形容词都有不同的含义。其中一个是'concerned'。在名词之前，它的意思是“担心的”，在名词之后，意思是“参与或受某物影响”。因此，一个担心的官员是指一个担心某事的人，而如果你想要联系负责某件事的官员，你应该写信给有关官员。试试: <suggestion>\2 \1</suggestion> </message>

en_msg: <message>'Conditionality' is a clumsy word that should be used parsimoniously. Moreover, it is not an erudite synonym of 'condition' but a derivative of 'conditional' and means simply 'the state of being conditional'. Finally, it is an uncountable noun that cannot be used in the plural, despite the 156 plural hits in Eurlex. Alternatives: <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">condition</match></suggestion> or 'the conditions imposed/set'.</message>
zh_msg: <message>'Conditionality' 是一个笨拙的词，应该少用。此外，它不是'condition'的同义词，而是'conditional'的派生词，意思是“有条件的状态”。最后，它是一个不可数名词，不能用复数形式，尽管在欧盟法律法规数据库中有156个复数。试试: <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">condition</match></suggestion> or 'the conditions imposed/set'.</message>

en_msg:
<message>In-house terminology uses 'conference' to refer to a simple talk or lecture, where one speaker comes to impart his knowledge on a given subject. In English, a conference is 'a high-level meeting for consultation or exchange of information or discussion with a number of speakers, often lasting several days', like the Kyoto conference, or in the legal context, a one-to-one meeting between a barrister and his client. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">talk</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">lecture</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">presentation</match></suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>The American heritage book of English usage states that, in 'consider as', the 'as' is 'not sufficiently well established to be acceptable in writing'. In any case, it is redundant. Alternatives: <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">consider</match></suggestion> or consider to be.</message>
zh_msg: <message>美国传统的英语用法手册指出，在'consider as'中，'as'“没有被充分确立以便被书面接受”。因此在任何情况下，它都是多余的。试试：<suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">consider</match></suggestion> or consider to be.</message>

en_msg: <message>'Contractual' means 'laid down in a contract' (e.g. 'contractual terms'), it does not mean 'under contract'. Although the term is widely used in this latter way in the institutions, it does not appear at all in the current Staff Regulations or in the Conditions of Employment of other Servants. Alternatives: <suggestion>contract staff</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg: <message>'Contractual'的意思是“合同中规定的”（例如：'contractual terms'“合同条款”），这并不意味着“受契约的约束”。尽管该术语在机构中被广泛使用，但在现行的工作人员条例或其他雇佣人员的条件里根本没有出现。试试: <suggestion>contract staff</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>'Contradictory procedure' does not exist in English as a fixed expression, although, of course, a procedure can be contradictory. The EU's financial regulation lays down '<suggestion>adversarial <match no="2" postag="(NN.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">procedure</match></suggestion>' as the technical term for the Court's hearing of the Commission with regard to its findings. However, 'contradictory procedure' is still used outside this context and we should bear in mind that people beyond our immediate circle will not understand it. In most cases, it is better to drop the legalese and rework the sentence in layman's terms.</message>
zh_msg: <message>尽管'Contradictory procedure'在英语中不是一个固定搭配，但一个过程当然可以是前后有矛盾的。 欧盟的金融监管规定'<suggestion>adversarial <match no="2" postag="(NN.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">procedure</match></suggestion> ' 是法院听取委员会关于其调查结果的技术术语。然而，'contradictory procedure'仍然在这种情况之外被使用，我们应该记住，超越我们圈子的人不会理解它。在大多数情况下，最好放弃法律术语并以外行人的条款重新处理该句。</message>

en_msg:
<message>To control does not usually mean 'to audit' 'check' or 'verify' and 'a control' is not normally 'a check' or 'an inspection'. Its most common meaning is 'to exercise authoritative or dominating influence over; direct'. Thus, if we say that 'the Commission controlled project X in the Member States', we do not mean that the Commission audited it, but that the Commission ran it. Used as a noun, we do not 'carry out' or 'perform' controls. Controls are more likely to be systems that are in place (passport controls, for example). Hence, we can say that the Court checked to see if the key controls were working, but not that it carried out controls. Furthermore, when talking about systems, the best term will often be 'safeguard'. Alternatives: 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">audit</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">check</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">verify</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">inspect</match></suggestion>, inspection, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">safeguard</match></suggestion>.
                </message>
zh_msg:
<message>控制通常并不意味着“审计”“检查”或“验证”，“控制”通常不是“检查”或“审查”。其最常见的含义是“行使权威的或主导的影响力;直接的”。因此，如果我们说“委员会控制成员国的X项目”，我们并不是说委员会对它进行了审计，而是委员会对它进行了操控。作为一个名词，我们不“执行”或“实施”控制。控制措施更可能是现成的系统（例如护照控制）。因此，我们可以说法院检查了关键控制措施是否有效，但不是它实施了控制措施。而且，在谈论系统时，最好的术语往往是'safeguard'（“保障”）。试试: 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">audit</match></suggestion> , 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">check</match></suggestion> , 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">verify</match></suggestion> , 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">inspect</match></suggestion> , inspection, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(VB.*)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">safeguard</match></suggestion> .
                </message>

en_msg:
<message>In British and Irish usage, a 'dean' is either a relatively senior priest or the head of a university faculty. At the Court of Auditors, on the other hand, it is the name given to the doyen or chair of the institution's audit chambers. 'Dean' is now the official title at the Court, but, in our dealings with the outside world, we should not be surprised if people think that we have our own in-house clergy. Alternatives: 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NN|NNS)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">chair</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NN|NNS)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">chairwoman</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN|NN(S)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1(:UN)?">chairman</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NN|NNS)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">chairperson</match></suggestion>,
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NN|NNS)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">doyen</match></suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>To debrief means 'to question (someone, typically a soldier or spy) about a completed mission or undertaking'. In the EU institutions, on the other hand, 'debriefing' is used to indicate 'a meeting for giving information or instructions'. This would be a <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">briefing</match></suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg: <message>To debrief就是要对完成的任务或任务提出询问（通常是士兵或间谍）。另一方面，在欧盟机构中，'debriefing'被用来表示“提供信息或指示的会议”。这将是一个 <suggestion><match no="1" postag="(NNS|NN:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="$1">briefing</match></suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>The Microsoft Word spell checker thinks that 'decommit' does not exist and the Oxford English, Oxford on-line, Merriam Webster and Macmillan dictionaries seem to agree. It follows that there is also no such thing as a 'decommitment'. Use: cancel.</message>
zh_msg: <message>微软的单词拼写检查器认为'decommit'并不存在，牛津英语、牛津在线、韦氏词典和麦克米伦字典似乎也同意这一点。由此可见，也没有所谓的'decommitment'。 用这个词：cancel.</message>

en_msg:
<message>'Deepen' is a difficult word to use figuratively. In addition to its literal meaning (e.g. deepen a well), it can also be used to mean 'to increase', 'improve' or 'boost'. However, it cannot be used indiscriminately in this way and, in this meaning, can actually only be associated with a few abstract terms like 'knowledge' or 'understanding'. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">improve</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">increase</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">bolster</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">boost</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">develop</match></suggestion>.</message>

            <suggestion>time <match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">limit</match></suggestion>,

            <suggestion>time allowed</suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>'Detached' means 'separated', 'disconnected' or standing apart from others (as in 'detached house') or, in the case of a person, 'marked by an absence of (emotional) involvement'. Alternatives: <suggestion>seconded</suggestion>, secondment.</message>

<message>'To do' is a rather weak word: 'to perform' and 'to carry out' are often better. Using them also avoids the all too common confusion between 'to do' and 'to make'. Alternatives: <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">perform</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">carry</match> out</suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">undertake</match></suggestion>.</message>

en_msg:
<message>A 'dossier' is a file. However, it is not a particularly common word and not one that readers will necessarily fully understand or even know how to pronounce. In EU texts, in addition to being overused, it is also employed metaphorically, where there is no actual file, to mean 'subject', 'issue' or 'question'. If you mean file, use 
            '<suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)?" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">file</match></suggestion>', otherwise 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)?" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1(:UN)?">question</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)?" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1(:UN)?">issue</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)?" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1(:UN)?">matter</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)?" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1(:UN)?">subject</match></suggestion> or even 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)?" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1(:UN)?">procedure</match></suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>'To ensure' means 'to make sure or certain'. However, it is often used in the EU to mean 'to provide'. 'Ensure' should never be followed by 'to' and an indirect object. Alternatives: provide with, <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">guarantee</match></suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>In English, as in other languages, global can mean both 'worldwide' and 'overall', but sometimes it can be a little confusing in this second meaning. Alternatives: <suggestion>general</suggestion> or <suggestion>overall</suggestion></message>

en_msg: <message>'Heavy' has a number of meanings, mostly to do with weight and thickness (heavy load, heavy fog). It cannot, however, be used to render the idea that a procedure or administration is excessively complicated, slow or difficult. As well as using 'heavy' itself, EUR Lex documents try to render this concept in a number of ways (cumbersome, burdensome, and even ponderous), but they rarely sound quite right. Alternatives: <suggestion>complicated</suggestion>, excessively or unnecessarily complex/slow, etc., often <suggestion>unwieldy</suggestion> (organisation, argument), or <suggestion>laborious</suggestion> (process, procedure).</message>
zh_msg: <message>'Heavy'有许多含义，主要与重量和厚度有关（重载，大雾）。然而，它不能用来说明程序或管理过于复杂、缓慢或困难。除了使用“笨重”本身含义外，欧盟法律法规数据库文件试图以多种方式渲染这个概念（繁琐、繁重、甚至笨重），但它们听起来都不太对。 试试: <suggestion>complicated</suggestion> , excessively or unnecessarily complex/slow, etc., often <suggestion>unwieldy</suggestion> (organisation, argument), or <suggestion>laborious</suggestion> (过程, 程序).</message>

en_msg: <message>'Important' is often wrongly used to mean 'big' ('the most important power station in France'); it actually means: 'strongly affecting the course of events or the nature of things' or 'having or suggesting a consciousness of high position or authority'. Alternatives: <suggestion>large</suggestion>, <suggestion>significant</suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>To incite means to 'encourage or stir up (violent or unlawful behaviour)' or to 'urge or persuade (someone) to act in a violent or unlawful way'. You cannot therefore incite someone to buy a car, use organic farming techniques or comply with a regulation. Alternatives: <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">encourage</match></suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg: <message>To incite意思是“鼓励或煽动（暴力或非法行为）”或“敦促或说服（某人）以暴力或非法方式行动”。因此，你不能煽动某人购买汽车，使用有机农业技术或遵守规定。 试试： <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">encourage</match></suggestion> .</message>

en_msg:
<message>'To inform' requires a direct object (inform the public/us/them etc.) and cannot be used without one except in passive sentences ('we were informed of something', for example). In some cases you can add the relevant object ('a number of Member States informed the Commission…'), otherwise, Alternatives: 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">announce</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">declare</match></suggestion>, 
                <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">state</match></suggestion>.</message>

en_msg:
<message>In international relations, the normal meaning of 'intervention' is 'interference by a state in another's affairs'. In EU parlance, it is just the term normally used to designate EU-funded operations in the member countries and elsewhere. In normal English usage, 'intervention' is often uncountable, leading to unwanted grammatical problems. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S|:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">activity</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S|:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">project</match></suggestion>, EU-funded activity.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>在国际关系中，'intervention'的正常含义是“一国干涉另一国内政”。用欧盟的说法，它只是通常用来指欧盟成员国和其他国家的资金运作的术语。在正常的英语用法中，'intervention'常常是不可数的，导致不必要的语法问题。试试: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S|:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">activity</match></suggestion> , 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S|:UN)" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">project</match></suggestion> , 欧盟资助的活动。</message>

            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">put</match></suggestion>/

en_msg:
<message>A 'jury' is 'a group of, usually twelve, people sworn to deliver a true verdict according to the evidence upon a case presented in a court of law'. The term is also sometimes used in talent shows. In English, it is never used in the context of recruitment. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion>selection <match no="1" postag="NNS?">board</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion>selection <match no="1" postag="NNS?">panel</match></suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>'jury'指的是一群人，通常是十二人，他们宣誓要根据法庭上的证据来做出真正的裁决。这个词有时也用于才艺表演。在英语中，它从来没有被用于招聘。试试: 
            <suggestion>selection <match no="1" postag="NNS?">board</match></suggestion> , 
            <suggestion>selection <match no="1" postag="NNS?">panel</match></suggestion> .</message>

en_msg:
<message>In EU English, a 'legislator' is a body, or, in the case of the EU, two bodies together ('the European legislator' = the Council and the Parliament). In regular English, a legislator is a person. Therefore, the word 'legislator' should be used to refer to a single MEP, not, for example, to the whole Parliament. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">legislature</match></suggestion>(= 'a body of persons having the power to legislate'), 
            <suggestion>legislative <match no="1" postag="NN(S)?" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1(:UN)?">body</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion>the Council and Parliament</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>在欧盟英语中，“立法者”是一个机构，或者在欧盟的情况下，指的是两个机构（“欧洲立法者”=理事会和议会）。在普通英语中，立法者是一个人。因此，“立法者”这个词应该用来指一个单一的欧洲议会会员，而不是整个议会。试试:

            <suggestion>the Council and Parliament</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg:
<message>'Mission' has a number of meanings, none of which corresponds to the way it is most commonly used in EU texts. Generally speaking, missions, in English, are performed by secret agents, astronauts or diplomats. Otherwise they can be the places where priests, nuns, diplomats etc. work abroad (often in developing countries). While it would be difficult to do without the word internally, we should bear in mind that it is likely to be misconstrued by outsiders. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">audit</match></suggestion>/
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">visit</match></suggestion> (at the Court of Auditors), sometimes 
            <suggestion>official <match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">trip</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion>official business</suggestion> or just 
            <suggestion>business</suggestion> or 
            <suggestion>work</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>'Mission'有许多含义，没有一个与它在欧盟文本中最常用的方式相一致。一般来说，英语中所说的missions是由秘密特工、宇航员或外交官执行的。除此之外，也可以是牧师、修女、外交官等在国外工作的地方（通常在发展中国家）。虽然在内部没有这个词是很困难的，但我们应该知道，它很可能会被外人误解。试试: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">audit</match></suggestion> /
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">visit</match></suggestion> (at the Court of Auditors), sometimes 
            <suggestion>official <match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">trip</match></suggestion> , 
            <suggestion>official business</suggestion> or just 
            <suggestion>business</suggestion> or 
            <suggestion>work</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg:
<message>'Modality' is one of those words which people (a) swear is correct and (b) say they have to use because the Commission does so (the example below is a case in point). The trouble is that it is not English – at least not in the meaning applied in our texts. EUR Lex contains over two thousand cases in which it is used to mean 'procedure', but this does not make it mean 'procedure'. In English, it is a rare and quite specialised word (only 50 or so hits in the British National Corpus), whose main meanings relate to grammar, philosophy, medicine and physiology. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">procedure</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">method</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">mode</match></suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>'Modality'是人们（A）发誓正确的话之一，（B）说他们必须使用，因为委员会这样做（下面的例子就是一个恰当的例子）。 问题在于它不是英语——至少在我们的文本中没有意义。欧盟法律法规数据库包含超过二千个案例，其中的意思是“过程”，但这个单词的意思并不是“程序”。在英语中，它是一个罕见且非常专业的词（在英国国家语料库中只有50个左右），其主要含义与语法、哲学、医学和生理学有关。试试： 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">procedure</match></suggestion> , 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">method</match></suggestion> , 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">mode</match></suggestion> .</message>

en_msg:
<message>In English, 'modulation' is only normally used in the fields of music and grammar and with regard to wave frequencies. In EU documents, it is used to mean reduction and, in the jargon of the common agricultural policy, refers specifically to a 'system of progressive reduction of direct payments allowing a transfer of funds from Pillar 1… to Pillar 2'. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">adjustment</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">reduction</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">increase</match></suggestion>. With reference to the common agricultural policy, if you use 'modulation', it must be explained.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>在英语中，'modulation' 通常只用于音乐和语法领域以及波频方面。在欧盟文件中，它被用来表示减少，用普通农业政策的术语来说，具体指的是“逐步减少直接支付的制度，允许将资金从第一支柱转移到第二支柱”。试试: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">adjustment</match></suggestion> , 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">reduction</match></suggestion> , 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">increase</match></suggestion> . 参照一般的农业政策，如果使用'modulation'，就必须加以解释。</message>

en_msg:
<message>In EU texts, the word 'name' is often used to refer exclusively to a person's surname, so we are asked to supply someone's 'name and first name'. In English, a person's 'name' is his/her whole name. The 'first name' should come first and the 'last name' last. Documents and forms in English should unambiguously specify which name is which, e.g. by using the neutral terms 
            <suggestion>given <match no="2" /></suggestion> and 
            <suggestion>family <match no="2" /></suggestion>. In running text (as opposed to forms or tables), the normal order should be retained.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>在欧盟的文本中，'name'这个词经常被用来指代一个人的姓，所以我们被要求提供'name and first name'（姓和名）。在英语中，一个人的'name'是他的全名。'first name'应该是第一位的，'last name'是最后一位。英语中的文档和表单应该明确指定哪个名称，例如，通过使用中性术语
            <suggestion>given <match no="2" /></suggestion> and 
            <suggestion>family <match no="2" /></suggestion> . 在运行文本时（与表单或表相反），应该保留正常的顺序。</message>

en_msg: <message>Normally means 'as a rule', 'usually', 'ordinarily' or 'in a normal manner' (e.g. 'act normally!'). In EU usage, it often expresses something that should happen. Use: 'supposed to', 'should', 'expected to'.</message>
zh_msg: <message>Normally意味着“通常”，或“以正常方式”（例如“表现得正常点！”）。在欧盟的用法中，它经常表达应该发生的事情。使用：'supposed to', 'should', 'expected to'。</message>

en_msg:
<message>In our administration, the word 'note' (dictionary definition = 'a brief letter, usually of an informal nature') seems to have invaded the semantic fields of both 'memo' ('a written communication, as in a business office') and 'letter' (many of our 'notes' are anything but brief, and none of them are informal). Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">memo</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN(S)|NN:UN" postag_regexp="yes" postag_replace="NN$1">letter</match></suggestion>.</message>

en_msg:
<message>We normally notify somebody of something, we do not usually notify something to someone. If you notify something to someone, you report it, formally, usually to some sort of authority. If you notify somebody of something, you inform them of it. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">send</match></suggestion>, provide… with, inform or notify somebody of something, report something to somebody.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>我们通常会通知(notify)某人某件事，我而不会把某事通知(notify)给某人。如果你把某件事通知(notify)某人，你就会正式地报告(report)，通常是有权威性的。如果你通知(notify)某人某件事，你就告知(inform)他们。试试: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">send</match></suggestion> , provide… with, inform or notify somebody of something, report something to somebody.</message>

en_msg: <message>EUR Lex has 1,057 hits for 'economic operator'. Although the term is not used in English in this way, I take it that these are simply companies or businesses. Similarly, on its own, the term 'operator' is used to cover a wide range of activities – in customs, it can mean 'importer' or 'exporter' or possibly 'shipping company': in agriculture, it can refer to farmers or people who market or process their produce etc. It would be clearer to call things by their own name – business if you mean business, farmer if you mean farmer, importer if you mean importer etc.</message>
zh_msg: <message>欧盟法律法规数据库中'economic operator'一词有1,057个点击量。虽然这个术语在英语中不是这么用，我认为这些仅仅只是公司或企业而已。同样，'operator' 一词本身就被用来涵盖范围广泛的活动——在海关中，它可以指“进口商”或“出口商”或可能是“运输公司”：在农业方面，它可以指农民或销售或加工他们的产品的人等等。通常以他们自己的名字称呼事情会更清楚——如果您的意思是生意，则用 business，指农民，则用farmer，指进口商，则用importer等。</message>

en_msg: <message>'Opportunity' does not mean 'the character of that which is opportune' (I am translating verbatim from a French dictionary). The English dictionary definition of opportunity is 'a favourable or advantageous circumstance or occasion or time' (as in 'I take the opportunity to wish you a merry Christmas.'). Alternatives: <suggestion>advisability</suggestion>, whether it was advisable to, whether it would be opportune to.</message>
zh_msg: <message>'Opportunity'并不意味着“恰当的特性”（我正在逐字翻译法语字典）。英语字典对机会的定义是“有利的或有利的情况或场合或时间”（如'我借此机会祝你圣诞快乐'）。试试: <suggestion>advisability</suggestion> , whether it was advisable to, whether it would be opportune to.</message>

en_msg: <message>EU 'orientations' are guidelines. Orientation, in English, is uncountable and means 'the act of determining one's bearings or settling one's sense of direction'. Alternatives: <suggestion>guidelines</suggestion>.</message>

en_msg: <message>Although the legal term 'prescription', meaning 'the limitation of time beyond which an action, debt, or crime is no longer valid or enforceable' is commonly used in Scottish law, the State of Louisiana and possibly Quebec, it is little known with this meaning in the rest of the English-speaking world. It is a convenient term, but unfortunately not one that most English speakers would understand. Generally speaking, <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">limitation</match></suggestion>. A 'statute of limitations' is said to apply: we can say, for example that there is a 'three-year statute of limitations', 'three-year limitation of action', 'three-year time-bar' or 'three-year limitation period'; if it is too late to pursue an action, we can say that 'the statute of limitations has run out'; if a debt can no longer be collected, we can talk of a 'time-barred' claim or offence. The terms 'stale claim' and 'stale offence' are rather nice, but less well-known.</message>
zh_msg: <message>虽然法律术语'prescription'，即“行动、债务或犯罪不再有效或可执行的时间限制”，在苏格兰法律、路易斯安那州，还可能在魁北克中都是常见的，但在其他的英语国家中，这一含义却鲜为人知。这是一个方便的术语，但遗憾的是，大多数说英语的人都不会理解这一点。一般来说 <suggestion><match no="1" postag="NN.*">limitation</match></suggestion> . 据说'statute of limitations'是适用的：例如，我们可以说，有“三年时效法令”，“三年行动时效”，“三年时间限制”或“三年时间限制的年限”;如果采取行动为时已晚，我们可以说“诉讼时效已经过期了”;如果债务不能再被收回，我们可以说“已经失去时效的”索赔或犯罪。 'stale claim'和'stale offence'这两个词相当不错，但不太知名。</message>

en_msg: <message>This is a risky term to use; although some dictionaries allow the meaning 'commonly known as', others, like the Collins dictionary, emphasise that its use casts doubt on the veracity of the term it introduces = 'called (in the speaker's opinion, wrongly) by that name'. Often, 'so-called' is superfluous and the other term can stand alone. In other cases we can say 'known as' or 'this is called'.</message>
zh_msg: <message>这是一个危险的术语;尽管一些字典有“通常被称为”的意思，但其他的字典，比如柯林斯字典，强调它的使用使人们对它所介绍的术语的真实性产生了怀疑，它被称为“（在说话者的观点中，错误地）”。通常，'so-called'是多余的，而另一个单词可以单独出现。在其他情况下，我们可以说'known as'或'this is called'。</message>

en_msg:
<message>'Suppress' is a bit like 'incite' in that it is often related to violence. It is also often combined with the adverbs 'savagely' or forcibly'.             <suggestion><match no="2" /> outside the EU</suggestion>/EEA etc.</message>

<message>美国是一个国家，加拿大是另一个国家，爱尔兰是第三个国家。美国可以与加拿大签署一项协议，将第三国（例如爱尔兰）排除在领海之外（例如捕鱼）。然而，在欧盟的文本中，这个术语被广泛用于指“欧盟以外的国家”，有时也指“我们正在谈论的任何一组国家之外的国家”。使用: 
            <suggestion>non-member <match no="2" /></suggestion> (or state), 
            <suggestion>non-Schengen <match no="2" /></suggestion> (or state), 
            <suggestion><match no="2" /> outside the EU</suggestion> /EEA etc.</message>

en_msg: <message>This is one of a series of gerunds used creatively but incorrectly as countable nouns, which is not generally possible in English. Training in English is a process (the process of being trained) and it cannot be used as a synonym for a '(training) course'. Alternatives: <suggestion>course</suggestion> (language course/I am on a course/I am doing a course), <suggestion>workshop</suggestion> (attending a workshop), presentation, talk etc.</message>
zh_msg: <message>这是一系列动名词之一，它创造性地使用了，但不正确地使用了可数名词的形式，这在英语中是不可能的。英语培训是一个过程（接受培训的过程），它不能被用作“（培训）课程”的同义词。试试: <suggestion>course</suggestion> (language course/I am on a course/I am doing a course), <suggestion>workshop</suggestion> (attending a workshop), presentation, talk etc.</message>

en_msg:
<message>'Transmit' normally refers to radio or television, data, and, possibly, the sadly defunct, Morse code. When sending something by letter, email or fax, we normally say 'send'. If we are sending something on that has been sent to us, we say 'forward' or 'send on' rather than 'retransmit'. Alternatives: 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">send</match></suggestion>, 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">forward</match></suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg:
<message>'Transmit'通常指的是广播或电视、数据，还有可能是已经失效的莫尔斯电码。当用信件、电子邮件或传真发送东西时，我们通常会说'send'。如果我们发送的东西已经发送给我们，我们说'forward'或'send on'，而不是'retransmit'。试试： 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">send</match></suggestion> , 
            <suggestion><match no="1" postag="VB.*">forward</match></suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>'Transverse' (meaning 'lying across; situated or lying crosswise or athwart') has 223 BNC entries, but these nearly all refer to the fields of medicine ('transverse colon', being the most common), natural science and mechanical engineering. Transverse is not used figuratively. Alternatives: <suggestion>cross-cutting</suggestion>, inter + something (interdepartmental, interministerial); sometimes just '<suggestion>broad</suggestion>' or '<suggestion>general</suggestion>'. Some rephrasing might be needed ('across the board', for example).</message>

en_msg: <message>'To valorise' means 'to fix and maintain an artificial price for (a commodity) by governmental action'. In EU texts, however, it is often used to mean 'to assign a value to' or to 'make the most of'. Alternatives: increase the value of, give a value to, enhance, make the most of, accentuate, upgrade, put to good use.</message>
zh_msg: <message>'To valorise'的意思是“通过政府行动来修复和维持（商品的）一个人为的价格”。然而，在欧盟的文本中，它通常被用来表示“分配一个价值”或“充分利用”。试试s: increase the value of, give a value to, enhance, make the most of, accentuate, upgrade, put to good use.</message>

en_msg: <message>Verification means 'the process of establishing the truth, accuracy, or validity of something'. It is an uncountable noun and does not normally have a plural. We do not, therefore, perform or 'do' (or even make) verifications in English. Alternatives: <suggestion>checks</suggestion>.</message>
zh_msg: <message>Verification是指“确定事物真相，准确性或有效性的过程”。这是一个不可数名词，通常不会有复数。因此，我们不会以英语进行或“做”（或甚至制造）verifications。试试: <suggestion>checks</suggestion> .</message>

en_msg: <message>Visa is misused to render not only 'approval', but also the act of giving approval. In English, a visa is generally 'an official authorisation appended to a passport, permitting entry into and travel within a particular country or region'. It is also the name of a credit card. Alternatives: approval, endorsement, to approve, to endorse.</message>
zh_msg: <message>Visa被滥用，不仅是“批准”，而且是给予批准的行为。在英语中，visa通常是“在护照上附加的官方授权，允许进入或在某个特定国家或地区旅行”。它也是一张信用卡的名字。试试：approval, endorsement, to approve, to endorse。</message>
